captions.text:
- My name is Ollie Streek
and this is my 1973 Datsun 240Z. My father

bought his car two or three years ago. It
got to the stage where I was driving it

more than he was and I was enjoying it. It
was the best car I've ever driven so it

came to the stage where I was sort of
started sourcing my own Datsun. I

collected this one from Copenhagen in
Denmark. It was fully restored when I

bought it and it started off as a bit of a
banger. It was a bit of a journey in

itself to go to Copenhagen. It was an 800
mile trip back. Literally as soon as I

brought it back I took it out the...
There's a Datsun specialist about 40

minutes up the road and I was offered
almost twice what I'd paid for it. Yeah,

my favorite characteristic about the car
is definitely the long nose and the short

back. It's very sort of Ferrari,
Daytona-ish and the Daytona's my favorite

car of all time, so, you know, it is the
cheaper way of getting what I wanted.

Compared to my Dad's one, it runs like...
It is perfect. Starts on the button every

time, no maintenance whatsoever, really. I
mean, it's been restored to a really high

standard and the engine's been rebuilt.
Nine original spec.

- The ratty has just got
something I really love about it. I just

love the rattiness of the car. As you've
seen earlier, if you lift the bonnet up,

you can see that the engine suspension and
all of the brakes and running is brand new

underneath and it's obviously a very fast
car as well, but it is a... It's

tremendous. I just love the look of it.
People keep saying to me, "Are you going

to paint it?" and I say "No, I'll leave it
as it is. That's exactly how I like it. "

When I was Ollie's age, I always remember
seeing him on the road and thought, "I'd

like one of those cars. That's what I want
and I couldn't afford it and I wasn't in a

position to be able to buy one when I was
20 but I did have a friend of mine who had

one and I used to look at it and think
"That is an amazing car. It's just like

having a Ferrari at 20." I've known the
car actually for a few years. I bought it

from a friend of mine and I've asked him
several times to sell it to me and

eventually he decided to... "Yup, we'll
let you have it." Now, he actually

regrets it and wishes
he hadn't sold it and from

what I understand he's actually
bought another one.

- Obviously both cars are very, very
different in style and most people think

that they're clean and Concord's car is my
Dad's and the rat look one is mine but

it's far from it. It's completely the
other way around. And it just so happened

that it wasn't intentional, really, and
yeah, the Ratsun's a little bit different

from anything else you've got in the shed,
here. It's a bit of a head turner and it's

absolutely bonkers. That captures more
attention, definitely, when you drive them

both through a street, but it sounds
superb. It's really cool.

- It's a completely different driving
experience. You come back, you've had a

drive and you know you've had a drive
because you're worn out. With that car,

the tires are so wide, suspension's
so hard

and it is an animal to drive. It
really is. Yeah.

- The Ratsun is a proper blood, sweat and
tears job. It's not an easy drive but it

is by far the most fun I've ever had
driving with a Ratsun.

- Yeah, I think Ollie would like this car.
If he had the choice. He keeps asking me

to buy this car and when
I wouldn't sell it to him,
he went out and bought his own car.

- I'd like to have his car as well. I'd
like to have both.

- Mine's the one that actually turns the
heads and people
take a second look at it. Definitely.

- It's nice 'cause you don't see so many
of these on the road. I think there's only

140, 150 of these in the country. I think
there's a fair few over in America but

over here they're a rarity. I haven't seen
another one on the road apart from the
ones we've got.

- Ollie and I often take the
cars out together and we take them on a

Sunday afternoon drive and go for a pint
or something and we enjoy looking at each

others cars as they're being driven.
Good.

- I'll never sell this car, I don't think.
I think I'll keep it for as long as I

live. It's quite special to me, so, yeah.
I don't see any...
There's no reason to sell it.

comments.text:
These Z's sound great on the outside once you wind them up, but they don't 
sound anywhere near as good on the inside. I would yank that motor and 
stick an LS in it, then have a near-perfect car that will surprise the hell 
out of whoever tries to outrun it.﻿
comments.author: Borderline5440

comments.text:
The thing is, crossplane V8s have gargling sound, and most other configs 
(from flatplane V8s to I6s to I4s to everything) have more of either 
roaring or screaming tone. Gargling works well with an imposing Corvette 
and really well with them muscles, but 240 is small and looks 
non-threatening, and heavy, bear-like sound will be completely out of 
character for it. It's like Peter Parker being played by Vin Diesel.
And it was your idea to stick an LS into Z. I've just implied that there 
are very few early Zs that could handle it well, and those that can are 
usually restored garage queens that'd be a waste to swap a V8 into (though 
you're right, I'm just an amateur).
comments.author: TheLaXandro

comments.text:
If you think LS motors don't sound good, you obviously haven't heard one 
that's been worked on, of any of the Corvettes/Camaros, etc. of the past 18 
years. And of course you can't simply stick an LS in a car that's got 
structural damage from being completely rusted out. That's so obvious that 
it doesn't even need to be said (unless you're dealing with a complete 
amateur, which I suspect you are).
comments.author: Borderline5440

comments.text:
>complains about sound
>wants to swap to a crossplane V8 because of it (crossplane V8s are kinda

>supposes that rusted out Datsun (and they're all rusted out, beieve me) 
could handle LS

comments.author: GT6SuzukaTimeTrials

comments.text:
+BottomDweller It's not fanboying if you have something logical to say that 
describes the car's history.  Glad to hear your knowledge is deeper and you 
found silver clouds behind the 500 lbs.  Unfortunately, all cars were 
suffering the same malady during the 70s, at least in the US.  They all got 
cranked up with smog and safety regs, and none of them were better for it. 
 But that's not Datsun's fault.  The world was becoming a smog shitehole, 
and the smog regs were needed.  Personally I think the extra weight of the 
5mph bumpers on all cars was a much greater sin, perpetrated by insurance 
companies to allegedly reduce parking lot trauma back to the consumer and 
their deductible.  If you bother to look 1970 had light, split bumpers on a 
lot of cars, which was super clean and didn't carry much weight.  But by 
1975, everything was changing in a way that destroyed many clean designs. 
 This weight as an asset would become a problem in years to come, as the 
IIHS would reward a generation of heavy SUVs and cagified sedans better 
ratings while ignoring the fact that the heavier vehicles became a greater 
liability to the safety of light cars.
comments.author: karlInSanDiego

comments.text:
+BottomDweller I don't believe that is correct. The 280Z with the L28E was 
only sold in the North American Market - the rest of the world outside of 
Japan continued to receive the L26 aka 260Z until the 1979 Model Year {late 
1978 calendar year} Datsun S130 280ZX / Nissan Fairlady 280Z. In Japan the 
Nissan Fairlady Z was sold with the L20/L20E until late calendar year 1978 
S130 - model year 1979. 330 Series Cedric got the L28 in 78.
comments.author: JeffSegan1

comments.text:
+JeffSegan1
L28 didn't come out anywhere until '75. The 260z was only available in '74 
in the US, with the same body as the '73 240z (with the exception of the 
new 5mph bumpers). '75 introduced the L28E everywhere, including the US. 
Cedric, Laurel, and Gloria all changed to the L28E in '75, when they 
introduced the L28 to the world market.
comments.author: BottomDweller

comments.text:
+tehmorbias  The US 260Z was rated at 165HP. The 260Z had the same body 
shell as the 240Z until the end of the Model Year - but the L28E was late 
getting released - so Nissan put the L26 in the new body shell for a couple 
months - until they released the 280Z with Fuel Injection for the North 
American Market for 1975
comments.author: JeffSegan1

comments.text:
+tehmorbias Yep, US cars. The 260Z we had was down on power, up on weight, 
and sat higher with the new bumpers. That was the first year we saw the 
2+2.
comments.author: jwojewidka

comments.text:
Well it depends; I take it you are talking about US cars. As far as I'm 
aware only the US version 260Z was gimped due to the emission regs at the 
time, here in the UK the 1974 260z had the same bodyshell as the 240z but 
the 2.6l engine put out 162bhp instead of the ~140bhp of the US version.
comments.author: tehmorbias

comments.text:
Best years were 71-73. 70 had some early design/build issues, one of which 
was exhaust fumes being sucked back into the car via boot lid vents. They 
were the lightest and most pure, and they had more HP than the 260Z, The 
280s were heavier, for sure, but they were fuel injected with a bit more HP 
and the interior materials were better. But from 260-280 they were sitting 
higher because of the bumper regulations, so they weren't quite as planted. 
The second best was the 77 with a factory 5-speed (which can be fitted to 
all of them), and which it really needed. 280 steering was noticeably 
heavier than the 240 and the whole experience was a bit different. It was a 
more deliberate drive. All the 2+2s were, of course, heavier and not quite 
as fun, nor have the timeless proportions. I've owned two 240s, one 260 and 
one 280. Will have another soon. Great fun to drive, listen to and look at.
comments.author: jwojewidka

comments.text:
280Z weighs like 500 lbs more than 240Z. The 240Z is the fastest of them 
all around a road course.
comments.author: GT6SuzukaTimeTrials

comments.text:
False? Same chassis, apart from minor differences. The 280z is the 
stiffest, and of the S30s, they have the largest diameter valves, the 260s 
have the 'hottest' cam, the series 1 240 E31 heads have the smallest quench 
area. All of them have their merits, and are regularly parts are swapped 
around both in and out of racing series. Hell, the basic premise of the 
motor in the IMSA cars was a 280z block with a 240z crank. Stop fan boying 
and learn a thing or two before spouting BS.
comments.author: BottomDweller

What's up with all these people spouting all this "rich kid" hate nonsense? 
 It's not as if Ollie here is driving a $80k Ferrari - he has a Datsun for 
crying out loud.  They aren't THAT expensive, so he has very likely paid 
for it with money he earned himself...  Get over yourselves, and stop being 
dicks.  

Anyway...

Two similar cars taken in very different directions, one is more focused on 
aesthetics and the other almost entirely on performance.  

Very much like the interior of the sons, with the custom quilted door 
panels, similar to original but nicer transmission tunnel quilt, and 
tasteful touches throughout.  Need those cracks on the dash repaired 
though, heh!  Also like the mirrors on it, different, but not too 
different.  I don't recognise that front air dam, anyone know who makes it? 
 Nice deep dish mesh wheels on it too!   

Would have been nice to hear, or even see, more of what the father has done 
to his Ratsun.  He mentions almost everything being new under the skin, so 
it would have been interesting to see how far he has taken it.  I obviously 
saw the triple Webers, which is always a worthwhile and intoxicating 
upgrade.  Nice, wide, Watanabe wheels with R888's tucked under ZG arches, 
very nice.  Wanted to see more though, instead of artistic close-ups that 
show almost nothing.  Interesting car, but this was just a tease...

Petrolicious:  Making this video 2 minutes longer and having some of the 
usual exterior parked shots would have been nice.  ﻿
comments.author: ryant67

comments.text:
Just paint the damn car, the ratrod look is perhaps ok, on some duff Yank 
car, but on a sportscar it is just plain stupid IMHO.  It is as dumb as the 
wrapping craze.   Painted, shiny cars, nice and straight always looks good, 
this one just looks like it is unloved and on the way to the knackers 
yard.  That is in good nick mechanically is great and for sure there is a 
good bond between the father and son.  Seeing what else is in the garage, a 
decent paint job would hardly be a problem I would have thought.﻿
